MWYvbBVGy_WAjAQ7TBkVUA.text: The meals are plentiful and delicious minus the veggies which leaves much to be desired. Good beer.  Must order from the bar.

A7u-krA80j1bWILQOreqnQ.text: Another of the Taylor & Walker chain of restaurants run by the "Spirit Pub Company". They seem to have gone around Central London (and some other UK locations ) buying up older English pubs and turning them into an english version of Applebees. They are OK.. but nothing special. A very bland and generic Pub experience. Just like the others no waitstaff (no matter what the review or chit on the table says). So you have to go the bar and order your food and drinks.

JjY7sUGxaVgYAjwgg3KQSg.text: Very standard pub located in front of Earl's court. It closes late, it has space for large group, an upstairs room with TV and crystal lights, plenty of beers, take cards.. and well that's it.Like many pub, it is a chain, don't expect magic to happen. It is very standard, and I guess that i why a lot of people likes it. If you are on this street, I would rather recommend the Prince of Teck's down the street. Much more cozy, a touch fancier, wayyy better to grab a drink and catch up with some friends.

ZLj3CjbMd6MKs-ZzugtctA.text: Not too shabby at all.  We've walked in - Jules in a Union Jack dress and me in a Union Jack jacket - and no one has batted an eye. Beer's good, prices pretty good and the food looks great. Sport on the telly and plenty of room upstairs too. Friendly vibe and directly opposite Earls Court tube station.

F5lwQMV9zwkVz0laXZQgvg.text: Never had a whiny queen but I also didn't have any sticky pudding or anything else except pints, football(aka soccer) on the telly, and a sandwich downstairs in the pub.  Please note, I never made it upstairs to the restaurant.    The staff were all friendly and I had a choice of four different cask beers to choose from.  In fact, the establishment has some sort of national distinction for their cask selection.  The Croque monsieur I had though was meh. There are many places to eat in the area and if you get off the main street, you'll find many small, busy establishments to choose from.  But if you want pints, and if you want cask ale followed with some football and friendly banter from someone rooting for the other team, this is the place.  That Sky license is key as not all pubs that have a TV have the ability to show soccer.  The place was full for both matches I saw and discussion's with strangers were frequent and friendly.  I'll definitely go back.

oSXFJaPcJ-rxe-5syTCj9w.text: don't be scared off by 3 stars - the food and service were good and I recommend for breakfast.  nothing fancy or interesting but tasty and filling for a good price.

mjZWMXXviEA8sKY8v7pGXg.text: It was our first night in London and we were exhausted from our train ride there from Paris so we wanted to find somewhere near our hotel room. The Courtfield was only a two minute walk from our hotel (The Trebovir Hotel). As we walked in, the atmosphere was rustic and appropriately worn out, but in a cozy this-is-clean way. When we found the staircase to the dining room upstairs, we were greeted by the waitress who seated us without hesitation. We ordered and food arrived quickly! I ordered a cocktail shrimp appetizer and my sister ordered their soup of the day, both very tasty! For our main dish, I got the salmon, which while it wasn't the most mindblowing soft, succulent salmon i ever ate, the portion and large sides are more than overcompensating for what the dish may be lacking in taste. My sister had the chicken, which tasted a lot better than the salmon. Their potato sides were INSANELY heavy (and delicious)! We didn't make it to dessert because the dinners were large, heavy and absolutely fulfilling!Our waitress was nice and accommodating and understanding that we are tourists and know absolutely nothing, which was nice, but it could also be because Earl's Court is such a tourist living spot and we were in the midst of the olympics for London.Otherwise, I would definitely recommend it for people in Earl's Court living nearby that wants a good, affordable and novel experience in what seems like a rustic and "traditional" london-like dining environment (but take it with a grain of salt, i'm American and is culturally idiotic to what real "london" is). But I would definitely stand behind the beautiful, rustic and antiquated atmosphere of the dining room, it played a part in our overall pleasant dining experience! It really set the tone of our first night in London!

photos.caption: Photo of The Courtfield - London, United Kingdom. Extremely fulfilling and heavy!

f6GIwP3P5Ny-3yvN24Ff1Q.text: A convenient pub located across the street from Earl's Court station. There are always some great cask ales available.

opyAbKpbVHFjZ_ec0N5bdQ.text: NOTE... I am writing a review for a pub about Decent Breakfast.  The staff was very friendly.  I had a traditional English breakfast and it did not disappoint...except for the small portion of bacon. :(

GGm5XW2AUyxyvSQS9rmP8g.text: Update: 28/10/2008 The pub is under new management, and seems to have improved hugely: the edgy atmosphere has gone and the service has also improved a lot. They also sell several real ales, so they seem to really be making an effort to turn te place around. They also have a later licence than the nearby Blackbird. The interior seems to have had something of a makeover, in the traditional style - lots of vermilion ceilings and dramatic draping curtains. The mix of customers is still varied, and it can get packed when Chelsea play at home, but it's moved from a place to be avoided to one where we've happily had a few drinks! ***********************This is the first pub you see emerging from Earl's Court tube station, and from the outside it looks like a nice, large, traditional pub. Don't be fooled: although the interior looks OK, and it serves real ale, the service has in our experience always been pretty unfriendly, and it seems to possess an edgy (unpleasant) atmosphere - perhaps because the SkySports on the huge TV screen, combined with the jukebox music, militates against sociability. I'd suggest walking the short distance to the Blackbird, nearby. Much nicer.

syPMym0fQSjMDqbuhssqdA.text: This is the pub for you...If you want a faceless pub like every other!Is that harsh? Should a pub be judged on it's grog, grub and service rather than compared to others? I don't know, if you decide differently to me, leave a review, but here's what I think...Being charged £5.30 for a shandy (I've lived in London too long) and a blackcurrant squash is painful enough, but no Yelper would let that cloud judgement. The tables are all square, and too close together. The food, nice as some as it is (I didn't try the sticky toffee pudding to be fair) you just know it is cash and carry microwaved stuff, even the beer tastes like a faceless chain pub beer, and I know you know what I mean. That said, this isn't an awful pub. On a sunny day, the light through the window is lovely, there are seats outside, and the staff were friendly. The price wasn't ridiculous for that area of London I guess. So it gets a star or two. Basically, when I go anywhere, pub, restaurant, cafe, shop, I want to go there, becuase I want to go THERE. The courtfields is a pub you go to cuz its convenient for the station (or for the sticky toffee pudding, but my mum makes the best sticky toffee pudding, sorry Amanda, it's a fact!)Meh, I've experienced better! 2 stars!

photos.caption: Photo of The Courtfield - London, United Kingdom

m4qykVwvYTN1_fMm4U76ag.text: I made a point of writing down the name of this pub so I could write a Yelp review when I got home- DO NOT GO TO THIS PUB.  The door was blocked by two 'security' in the middle of the day with about 8 people inside, needless and unfriendly as all get out, the waiter/bartender was the most condescending ass - do not waste your money, there are SO many places to eat and drink in London, avoid this place, even if you need food right off the Earl's Court station, there's tons of places to go besides this place.

5bBZmAS1Svj6Y0V_Ox9JKg.text: Day 1 in London and the fam sets out to find breakfast, after sleeping past the free breakfast in our hotel. About a block out, we find the Courtfield and see their sign for "traditional English breakfast" for something like 4.99 pounds. Even converted into dollars, that's more than decent, so we give it a shot.My parents ordered the traditional, while I opted for their salmon and eggs. Delicious! The smoked salmon was very fresh and the eggs and toast were great too. Nothing fancy, but good taste. And my coffee...oh man. Once I figured out that "white coffee" means "with milk," I ordered the best coffee with milk I think I've ever had. I also really liked that the patrons weren't just tourists from the surrounding hotels. I love Brit-speak as much as any other California girl, and knowing that locals visit the establishment gives it extra points.

K96Mrixj00LafQL9cq95Kw.text: If you're visiting from the States (and if you're on Yelp then there's a good chance that you are) and if you're asking "Is this a good pub?" (and again, if you're on Yelp then there's a good chance that you are) then the answer is "not really."It's neither good nor bad.  The £4.99 full English breakfast is quite a good deal, it's just not an outstanding full English breakfast.  And aside from that breakfast, most everything else here is overpriced and not very good.  They do have table service so you don't have to order at the bar, which is a welcome rarity at a pub.Given its location directly opposite Earl's Court tube station and the aforementioned cheap breakfast, this place pulls in lots of tourists and commuters, but mostly tourists.The one really good thing that The Courtfield has going for it is that it opens early (I think 8 am) and stays open until midnight.  It also has free WiFi, although you'll frequently need to ask them to reset the router.  That was the only reason I ever came here, as I live close by and needed somewhere to get online before we got internet installed in our flat.On the flip side, there's this obnoxious whiny queen who works there who makes the experience almost unbearable.  Don't get me wrong, I'm not homophobic - I just don't like obnoxious whiny queens.  One time I was there and three Italian ladies (see "lots of tourists" above) ordered a round of machiattos.  In his most obnoxious whiny queen voice, her majesty snapped at them, "What's thaaaaaaaaaat?????"  The Italian ladies just looked at him with that "Are you serious?" look, and not in the sense that they were shocked that he didn't know what a machiatto was (but seriously - what self-respecting gay guy doesn't?), but more in a "What's with the fucking attitude, buddy?" kind of look.Another time I took my wife here and I warned her about her majesty.  We were sitting down looking at a menu and the obnoxious whiny queen came up to us and (seemingly politley) asked, "Did you want to order something?"Thinking that he was offering to take our order, my wife began to reply "Yes, I'll have the-""Oh FINE! I guess I'll just play waiter then!" her majesty snorted, cutting her off and storming away.Needless to say, we haven't been back since.

QLp3kH55mc0oOVKDjDw9cA.text: 3 words: Sticky.Toffee.Pudding3 more words: Oh.My.GodSitting at my desk I'm day dreaming of their sticky toffee pudding. So moist, so sweet, so god damn delicious. The entire week we were in London every night I wanted to go back just to have it again. I would fly back out to London TODAY just so I could have that deliciousness in my mouth again. My mouth is watering right now as I type these words. Besides the magnificent toffee pudding, this place is alright. Beer offerings are a little weak but I'm not sure if the options downstairs in the pub section are different than the dining room. My chicken stuffed with asparagus was very good, and I snuck a bite (or 10) of Joe's pie and it was quite tasty. Heavy food, you will definitely be dragging yourself out but the end of the meal. Service was slow but very nice.Just make sure you leave room for the sticky toffee pudding.  5 billion stars for the sticky toffee pudding, 3 for the overall pub.

Xyp1w3eJHbFZ6sH4PD76gA.text: Great ale (Umu) and perfect fish and chips (The Codfather). We loved it!

STEYKdofSWzO_DJ5gwVICQ.text: The pub was the first one you will see when you come to Earls court.It was refurbished recently and open the first floor as the restaurant.The atmopshere in the pub was just so so,the drink was not very impressive too.They have a good range of food choices but the price was not that competitive.There were many other eating place in this area which were better.There were also blackbird and king's head nearby.Little far down the road was O'neills which offers very good price for food.

_PNpHfJZhzt9REjH0_ZqxA.text: The Courtfield is a decent traditional pub, located diagonally from Earl's Court Underground station. It offers the usual solid pub food (including various breakfast options) and a better-than-average selection of alcoholic beverages, including some real ales. Atmosphere is nice, staff usually friendly and helpful. One of the more stylish options in the area décor-wise. Beers don't come cheap though, and if Chelsea have a home game, beer will be served from plastic cups. Recommended.

photos.caption: Photo of The Courtfield - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Courtfield - London, United Kingdom

io21MqQRMcYrm7MT9KOrOA.text: Went here looking for a nice English breakfast what we got was ignored by the wait staff and horrible customer service Do yourself a favor and skip this pubPlenty more around the corner 0 stars !!!!!

A0_TaaIrgqK-QGps6_Bo9g.text: On a recent visit to London I attempted to visit this place three separate times. On the first, a bartender told us to take a seat and they'd be with us shortly. After ten minutes of being ignored, we were then told we should have placed an order at the bar. We left.On the second try we went in - the place was packed, and it was unbelievably hot inside. Not wanting to sweat through a whole meal, we left.On the third try I went to the bar to get a beer, wanting something on tap. I was told that only three beers were available: Stella Artois, Fosters and Estrella. This seemed ridiculous to me, and I didn't want beers I could get anywhere. Considering that there were plenty of patrons around drinking all kinds of beers, I got the sense that they may have been lying to me. I left.I won't be trying to go back.

mlHvjF2j7iJ7mGfuUbJ84A.text: Ordered the Vegitable Nachos as an appetizer and was fairly disappointed.  Minimal cheese on it, came to our table relatively cold, salsa tasted like ketchup and tasted like it was all microwaved.  The main courses were surprising delicious though!

i1Yxx9LyBdc3LfRxNPNvew.text: Ended up in the area intending to hit up Blackbird, only to find their kitchen closed. Luckily, the Courtfield was more than willing to accommodate us, and we had a great steak and ale pie. The fish and chips another member of our group ordered was just okay. Standard draft selection, lots of booths and TVs. Good people-watching out the window, surprisingly busy area for being a bit out of the way.

photos.caption: Photo of The Courtfield - London, United Kingdom. Steak and ale pie
Photo of The Courtfield - London, United Kingdom. Bite
Photo of The Courtfield - London, United Kingdom. Fish  and chips

AcqU4fhwgYw6NbaGwbJkTg.text: The Courtfield has become my go to pub in London for a casual evening or to watch a game.  It's an easy-going atmosphere and does not get too rowdy.  The location is across from the Earl's Court Underground, so if you decide to continue on your night out, it is easy to access the rest of the city.  The food here is pretty standard, so if you're hungry you can eat without fear of disappointment.

y8d2eIDBuQzR5bn2lUKBpg.text: We jumped off the tube at Earl's Court simply to check out the police box (or is it a Tardis - I'm actually not all that sure anymore because most people would see it as a Tardis despite the fact that those police boxes being rather common on London streets back in the early days of Doctor Who), and decided to grab a beer at the pub that happened to be the closest, which was basically this one. Well, it was okay, though considering the time I'm not all that surpised that it was quite crowded. I didn't mind it but it wasn't one of the best. Still, having a Tardis across the road is still pretty cool.

photos.caption: Photo of The Courtfield - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Courtfield - London, United Kingdom

ubZBG_GJ4MmQbQYOWC8Y5Q.text: Such a conveniently located pub across the street from the Earl's Court Station and within a 1.5 block walk from a series of hotels nearby.We dropped by on a Sunday morning at about 9:30am and the pub was almost completely empty, less another couple. The pub space was huge with plenty of tables and seats on the 1st floor. Yes, there's even a 2nd floor to this spacious pub. There was 2 TVs on the 1st floor meaning this probably isn't a spot people congregate to watch games, but to really chill and relax.We came here to exclusively try an English Breakfast in London and that is EXACTLY what we both ordered. The English Breakfast comprised of 2 sunny side up eggs, beans, 2 small sausages, a slice of ham, half of a tomato, a mushroom and toast. To summarize, the breakfast was really tasty and just what we expected. It was a perfect combination of breakfast foods on 1 plate.Nothing in the breakfast was bad, but at the same time nothing surprised us. It's not like it was something we couldn't make at home, but it was sort of a bucket thing to do in London and something everyone should try in London!

photos.caption: Photo of The Courtfield - London, United Kingdom. Breakfast Menu
Photo of The Courtfield - London, United Kingdom. Interior
Photo of The Courtfield - London, United Kingdom. The Full English

CE7tT9ujeWA1HPdJ81nKAg.text: Nearby pubs were too packed so we decided to try The Courtfield.  My husband went to the bar to order 2 fish n chips, and a pint for him and Bloody Mary for me.  Unfortunately, they informed him they were out of tomato juice so no Mary.  So I sent him back up for a Martini...this time the girl said no, no mixed drinks.  My husband asked if they realized they had mixed drinks on their menu, at which point they replied yes. .  Next our fish comes out, looks great, but zero flavor....zero...bland does not even describe the batter, and incredibly greasy.   Not a place I would recommend...but probably fine for stopping in for a beer.

1cFEk_IdXysZFTRkOPbkpQ.text: Great place right by my hotel when I was in London last week good drinks even doe a but pricey food was totally worth it. Fish & chips mate !!!

photos.caption: Photo of The Courtfield - London, United Kingdom. Everything I expected... Damn just made myself hungry...

qSRcQ4MGr1GGzBKt4hYutw.text: The bar staff is great, really attentive. However, the food seems institutional. There is no love in the food. I ordered the chicken and mushroom pie and I swear they gave me boxed mashed potatoes. It was tasteless and bland but smooth and I felt with the lack of lumps it was boxed. Plus, the carrots weren't peeled, which put me off. The pie came with a puffed pastry top that had a lot of depth. However, the pastry case for the pie was hard and inedible. Again, kudos to the staff, it was a busy Saturday afternoon during the showing of the Grand National and they really held the place together. What came out of that kitchen was a disappointment. I doubt I'll go back.

SjLO9cLYbEXjxvRzLpfJQQ.text: Wandering around Earls Court neighborhood, we walk into the Courtfield for some fish and chips. We're from San Francisco  by the way. So the menu offers peas or mushy peas. New choice for us, so we discuss it. When I say peas or mushy peas, half the pub yells "MUSHY." So we did. We enjoyed them so much that when we got home, we got on Amazon and ordered the dry peas to cook at home, quite successfully I might add.The fish and chips were great too. We highly recommend the Courtfield.

photos.caption: Photo of The Courtfield - London, United Kingdom

LlQhC3WSRAbdOo_wkN_wPw.text: After having a bad fish and chips experience decided to give it a shot here.... it was amazing!!! Really good crispy and flaky cod!!! Happy hour I think it was 3-5 ... buy a cocktail or beer get one Free!!!!! Nice pub

gxLlhXr4Tp3IFgJy_cgbGQ.text: The sign outside of this pub location was Greene King, and our receipt showed Taylor Walker, so there seems to be an identity confusion with this pub.  Nonetheless, whatever they want to call themselves, we visited the pub at 187 Earls Court.This pub is very convenient, just mere steps from the Earl's Court station.  The pub was not crowded during our visit.  It was not clear that we had to order food at the counter, so we sat at the table where menus were displayed.  We finally flagged down a staff after a 10 minute wait, and was told that we needed to go to the counter to order, but since the pub is not busy, he will service us at the table.  Our first night dinner in London, so Hubby and I both ordered the traditional fish and chips.  The food was so horribly bland.  Even the tartar sauce had no seasoning.  We incorrectly assumed that since we were in a pub, there would be adults, but a family with two toddlers arrived and took the table next to us.  These toddlers kept climbing up and down the shared banquet seating and screaming.  Needless to say, it was the least enjoyable dinner we had in London in both taste and atmosphere.  Not to mentioned, it was pretty pricey at £31.08 for two tasteless fish and chips and no alcohol.

i8ovj-_k8_ehkLlTSMrzFA.text: This place sucks. First, this is a chain. We made the mistake of thinking it was authentic; don't be fooled. (If you want something authentic, try the Prince of Teck across the street). The fish and chips was not good, it tasted like manufactured cardboard. The Sunday roast was equally as bad. The service was also rude and tried to rush out. If you're thinking of it, don't do it. There are better places on the block.

fQPBC_s-RzIZ2pam7Ci9rw.text: Expensive pub in West London. Pint of cask beer will set you back around £4.70 - there's no need for this at all. There's a section just for food and lots of TVs for football. Seems to be a Chelsea pub on their match days. Easily in reach of Earl's Court Tube station.

Hob84o0TV4yJ1dJ0B8Q1ag.text: Fantastic. I absolutely love this place. I have met so many characters from all over the world here. Every time, I have felt like I was meetings with friends. Bartenders are great, and the food is rather amazing. Broad beer selection, and outdoor seating with heaters. You can just watch all the people fleeting by outside, which seems never ending - like the traffic on Earls Court Road. I think this is the best bar in the whole neighborhood. There is upstairs seating also.

DL7IXhoKPkO2cuCYYXMjGw.text: Dont go here if you're non white because the euro trash behind the bars are biased and rude

Rk0bgnVFtWdB23nnOxXSAw.text: We ventured here this morning in search of the full English breakfast I've been hearing about. It was filling and tasty yet wasn't something I'd order again. There are cheaper breakfast spots close by. The waiter/ owner(?) was so friendly and talkative. His son worked there as well. I  took a look at the dinner menu and the fish and chips were £12+ which is ridiculous considering the number of places that are close by and much less expensive.

photos.caption: Photo of The Courtfield - London, United Kingdom. Little soldiers breakfast
Photo of The Courtfield - London, United Kingdom. Full English breakfast
Photo of The Courtfield - London, United Kingdom. Breakfast menu

JJlFuAHVNEhVIAEf3w4Tvw.text: After a 4am alarm call, a snack size bacon roll on the flight, this was a perfect pick me up! Great location close to hotel and Earls Court Tube station.

photos.caption: Photo of The Courtfield - London, United Kingdom. 3rd Breakfast
